page.title: 18Crayke and St Cuthbert
page.content: In AD 685 King Ecgfrith gave to St Cuthbert, Bishop of Lindisfarne the village of creka and around it an area of three miles circumference. It was inherited by succeeding bishops of Durham and was prt of Durham County for all purposes. By the 16th century the North Riding was able to exercise the law in Crayke by Reform act of 1832 the Township of Craik of Craikshire' was united to the County of york for parliamentary representation. In 1827 the bishop sold his crayke Estate but retained the rectory Finally in 1844 Crayke was united to the North Riding for all purposes. A reminder of the past is a public house called the 'Durham Ox'.
